meanings.definition: Quench or satisfy (one's thirst or desire)
meanings.sent1: After playing outside in the sun, I needed to slake my thirst with a cold glass of water.
meanings.sent2: The hiker stopped at the stream to slake his thirst before continuing on the trail.
meanings.sent3: The delicious smoothie was able to slake my thirst for something sweet and refreshing.
meanings.sent4: Her kindness was like a cool drink of water, able to slake the thirst of those around her.
meanings.sent5: The rain finally came, a downpour that seemed to slake the earth's thirst after a long drought.

meanings.definition: To cool or refresh by wetting
meanings.sent1: The children ran through the sprinkler to slake themselves on a hot summer day.
meanings.sent2: The gardener used a hose to slake the plants in the garden during the dry spell.
meanings.sent3: The puppy jumped into the pool to slake itself and cool down from the heat.
meanings.sent4: The cool breeze from the ocean seemed to slake the overheated tourists on the beach.
meanings.sent5: The ice-cold lemonade was able to slake my thirst and refresh me on a scorching day.

meanings.definition: To make less intense or severe
meanings.sent1: Taking a deep breath helped to slake my rising anger before I said something I would regret.
meanings.sent2: The apology was able to slake the tension in the room and bring a sense of peace.
meanings.sent3: His joke managed to slake the seriousness of the situation and bring a moment of levity.
meanings.sent4: The soothing music seemed to slake the stress in my mind, allowing me to relax.
meanings.sent5: The sunset painted the sky in vibrant colors, slaking the harshness of the day with beauty.
